title: 108_hr1874
content: The Act titled "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" clarifies the definition of homebound through a demonstration project. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" establishes a demonstration project for Medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions to receive home health services. Eligibility criteria include a permanent and severe condition, requiring assistance with daily living activities, and needing home health services. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" establishes a demonstration project for Medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions to receive home health services. The project requires individuals to have a functional condition that allows them to leave home with assistance, either technological or from another person. The Secretary will collect data on the quality of care, patient outcomes, and any additional costs to the Medicare program. Reports to Congress will be submitted one year after the implementation of the project. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on the project using data collected. Waiver authority allows the Secretary to waive compliance with certain requirements for demonstration projects. Construction section clarifies that penalties still apply under the Social Security Act. Authorization of appropriations is provided from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund. The Secretary can appropriate funds from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund for a demonstration project. Definitions include "Medicare beneficiary," "home health services," and "activities of daily living." The Secretary of Health and Human Services can appropriate funds for a demonstration project related to home health services, including activities of daily living such as transferring, bathing, and dressing. Clarification of the definition of homebound for determining eligibility for home health services under the Medicare program. Clarification of the definition of homebound for eligibility for home health services under Medicare is amended to include individuals with permanent and severe conditions requiring assistance with daily living activities. The Secretary cannot disqualify individuals from being considered 'confined to his home' based on absences for necessary medical services. The definition of homebound for Medicare eligibility is clarified to include individuals with severe conditions needing help with daily activities. A report on a demonstration project's impact on home health services must be submitted by the Secretary by December 1, 2006, with amendments taking effect on January 1, 2007 if no significant findings are reported. The Secretary's report must include data showing how the clarification of homebound definition affects home health services and Medicare expenditures. The Secretary's report must include data on the impact of clarifying the homebound definition on home health services and Medicare expenditures. Additionally, there are technical amendments to sections of the Social Security Act related to leaving home for home health services under the Medicare program. The seventh sentence, as specified in the Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Benefits Improvement and Protection Act of 2000, is added to the end of the section.
